00001 <h2>Instructions</h2>
00002 <p>
00003         <code>batterystat</code> is a commandline tool to print battery status information.
00004 </p>
00005 <p>
00006         The following options are available:
00007 </p>
00008 <dl>
00009         <dt>-a</dt>
00010         <dd>Connect to remote battery address.</dd>
00011         <dt>-c</dt>
00012         <dd>Prints the count of locally installed batteries and exits.</dd>
00013         <dt>-m</dt>
00014         <dd>Prints additional battery hardware information like manufacturer, manufacture date etc.</dd>
00015         <dt>-n #</dt>
00016         <dd>Request information for battery at position #. This is only meaningful for multiple battery systems like Pismo laptops. Default is 1.</dd>
00017         <dt>-p</dt>
00018         <dd>
00019                 Return the value of a single property. Allowed property names are: charge, amperage,
00020                 capacity, maxCapacity, designCapacity, voltage, cycleCount,
00021                 plugged, charging, manufacturer, manufactureDate, serial, deviceName,
00022                 timeToEmpty, timeToFullCharge. If not used, all properties are returned.
00023         </dd>
00024         <dt>-t</dt>
00025         <dd>Include time information.</dd>
00026         <dt>-v</dt>
00027         <dd>Prints version information and exits.</dd>
00028         <dt>-x</dt>
00029         <dd>Prints output in XML format.</dd>
00030 </dl>
00031 <p>
00032         Sample output:
00033 </p>
00034 <pre>
00035 maia:~ delphine$ batterystat
00036 Charge:                                97 %
00037 Capacity:                            2666 mAh
00038 Max Capacity:                        2727 mAh
00039 Design Capacity:                     4400 mAh
00040 Amperage:                               0 mA
00041 Voltage:                            12374 mV
00042 Cycle Count:                          131
00043 Power Source:                    AC Power
00044 Charging:                              No
00045 
00046 maia:~ delphine$ batterystat -c
00047 1 installed batteries.
00048 
00049 maia:~ delphine$ ./batterystat -h
00050 batterystat (c) Claudio Procida 2006-2008
00051 Usage: batterystat [options ...]
00052 Options:
00053 -a    Connect to remote battery address.
00054 -c    Prints count of local batteries and exits.
00055 -m    Include battery hardware manufacturing information.
00056 -n    Index of battery for which you want information. Defaults to 1.
00057 -p    Return the value of a single property. Allowed property names are: charge,
00058       amperage, capacity, maxCapacity, designCapacity, voltage, cycleCount,
00059       plugged, charging, manufacturer, manufactureDate, serial, deviceName,
00060       timeToEmpty, timeToFullCharge. If not used, all properties are returned.
00061 -t    Include time information.
00062 -v    Prints version number and exits.
00063 -x    XML output.
00064 -?/-h Prints this screen and exits.
00065 
00066 maia:~ delphine$ ./batterystat -n2
00067 No such battery.
00068 
00069 maia:~ delphine$ ./batterystat -p charge
00070 97
00071 
00072 maia:~ delphine$ ./batterystat -p manufacturer
00073 Sony
00074 
00075 maia:~ delphine$ ./batterystat -x 
00076 &lt;?xml version=&quot;1.0&quot; encoding=&quot;utf-8&quot;?&gt;
00077 &lt;battery xmlns=&quot;http://burgos.emeraldion.it/mbl/&quot;&gt;
00078         &lt;charge&gt;97&lt;/charge&gt;
00079         &lt;capacity&gt;2666&lt;/capacity&gt;
00080         &lt;maxCapacity&gt;2727&lt;/maxCapacity&gt;
00081         &lt;designCapacity&gt;4400&lt;/designCapacity&gt;
00082         &lt;voltage&gt;12378&lt;/voltage&gt;
00083         &lt;amperage&gt;0&lt;/amperage&gt;
00084         &lt;cycleCount&gt;131&lt;/cycleCount&gt;
00085         &lt;plugged&gt;1&lt;/plugged&gt;
00086         &lt;charging&gt;0&lt;/charging&gt;
00087         &lt;timeToEmpty&gt;-1&lt;/timeToEmpty&gt;
00088         &lt;timeToFullCharge&gt;-1&lt;/timeToFullCharge&gt;
00089         &lt;manufacturer&gt;(null)&lt;/manufacturer&gt;
00090         &lt;manufactureDate&gt;(null)&lt;/manufactureDate&gt;
00091         &lt;deviceName&gt;(null)&lt;/deviceName&gt;
00092         &lt;serialNumber&gt;(null)&lt;/serialNumber&gt;
00093 &lt;/battery&gt;
00094
